title: A Bolder New Wave of Scandinavian Design for 2025
description: The Nordic style has always been close to my heart because it’s calm, clear, and connected to nature. There is nothing more grounding and inspiring to me than a neutral living space with a few colors as accents - think rust red, terracotta, green or dusty rose. But in 2025, Scandinavian design feels a bit more rebellious…
author: Holly Becker

title: Core77 Weekly Roundup (7-14-25 to 7-18-25)
description: Here's what we looked at this week:Scooter design continues to evolve with China's OMO X. Will Honda's designers take notice? The U.S. military's robot coyotes. Not exactly terrifying, but they do the trick.The GEM is an indoor/outdoor EV ambulance.Bentley's experimental assymetrical EXP 15 concept car.At Zion Canyon, a new hot springs resort designed by HFA Architecture + Engineering.So apparently luxury board games are a thing.A very unusual Midcentury Modern chair of Dutch design.A utilitarian design classic: The Scaleo folding ladder, by industrial designers Roberto Lucci and Paolo Orlandini, 1974. An innovative UX detail: Peak Spec's GhostClip pocket knife has a clip that retracts.LG's StanbyME 2, a portable 27" TV and external monitor.D'ttach's smart, simple invention turns zero-turn mowers into four-season revenue generators.Adidas' new 3D-printed Climacool Laced sneakers.Artists/designers Julius von Bismarck and Benjamin Maus created "Round About Four Dimensions," an eye-popping kinetic represenation of a tesseract.The Termitat, by museum exhibit designer Christopher Poehlmann, is a tabletop termite habitat. Turns out the "pests" serve an important ecological function. A nifty solution to the corner kitchen drawer problem, and one funny fail.Graphic designer Drew Tetz's crazy animated vinyl LPs.Four design tricks for tight spaces in RVs, by German manufacturer Bürstner.Industrial design case study: Official Use Only's Dollight lamps spawn a new company.
author: Rain Noe

title: Industrial Design Case Study: Customizable 3D-Printed Lamps
description: The Dollight lamp is by San-Diego-based industrial design firm Official Use Only. Created under the motto "When personal design meets custom manufacturing," the challenge was to reconcile mass production with individual customization. And the design work was only half of it: OUO founder Michael Kritzer formed Dolop, a separate company, to produce the lamps. The challenge every design brand faces: How do you create meaningful, customizable products without the compromises of mass production or the exclusivity of full custom work?Our solution for dolop: We developed a collection of sculptural table lamps inspired by Japanese Kokeshi dolls. Each Dollight is 3D-printed fresh when ordered, offering 100+ combinations through food-inspired colors and textures, while connecting every purchase to charitable causes through the Sweetest Slice Program. The result: A new model for artisan-scale manufacturing that's both accessible and personal—where technology enables designer oversight at every step, customers get truly custom pieces, and every purchase creates positive community impact.Made fresh when ordered. Designed to bring joy without demanding attention. The Full StoryThe Challenge That Sparked InnovationThe Problem: The lighting industry forces customers into an impossible choice: mass-produced products that lack personality, or custom work that's prohibitively expensive and exclusive. Meanwhile, design brands who want to create meaningful objects face the same dilemma—compromise vision for scale, or limit impact to the few who can afford bespoke work.The Brand Reality: dolop wanted to create something deeply personal—lighting inspired by family members while making family-inspired design accessible to others without losing the intimacy that makes it special. The Manufacturing Challenge: Traditional production requires massive upfront investment, minimum orders, and inventory risk. Custom work requires individual attention that makes pricing unrealistic for most customers.The Market Gap: No one had figured out how to make truly customizable, designer-quality lighting that was both personal and accessible, while maintaining direct designer involvement in every piece. The Strategic BreakthroughInstead of choosing between mass production and custom work, we found the sweet spot: on-demand 3D printing that enables artisan-scale manufacturing with designer oversight. Each Dollight is made fresh when ordered, allowing infinite customization without inventory risk.Why Japanese Kokeshi Dolls as Inspiration: These traditional wooden dolls represent the perfect balance of simplicity and personality—each one unique yet unmistakably part of a family. They became the perfect metaphor for lighting that brings character without overwhelming a space.The Food-Inspired Language Strategy: By naming colors after foods (Ananas, Tomato, Matcha, Cotton Candy), we made technical choices feel warm and accessible. Customers aren't choosing "RAL 1028 Yellow"—they're choosing "Ananas" because it makes them smile.The Charitable Connection Innovation: The Sweetest Slice Program connects each color family to local San Diego charities, so every purchase creates community impact. Your lighting choice becomes a values choice, adding meaning beyond the object itself. The Transformation ResultsManufacturing Revolution: No inventory, no waste, no compromise. Each Dollight is 3D-printed in dolop's San Diego workshop only after purchase, using premium bio-based materials from corn and sugarcane. The founder personally oversees every piece from digital file to finished lamp.Customization Without Complexity: Over 100 combinations through 16 food-inspired colors and multiple textures, but the selection process feels intuitive rather than overwhelming. Customers create something uniquely theirs without needing design expertise.Family Stories Made Universal: Each design (Sweet, Bright, Smooth, Rich, Savory) captures the personality of a family member, but translates into lighting that works in any home. Community Impact Integration: The Sweetest Slice Program means every color choice supports local causes—education, healthcare, conservation, food security. Beautiful lighting becomes beautiful impact.Personal Connection at Scale: Every customer receives a personal note, 30-day returns with no restocking fees, and ongoing support through the Diffuser Replacement Program. Technology enables personal attention, not elimination of it.New Manufacturing Model: dolop proves that design brands can stay personally involved while making their work accessible. The brand demonstrates the future of American manufacturing where creativity, technology, and community impact converge. You can see more of OUO's work here.
author: Rain Noe

title: How to Easily Keep Butcher Block Counters Looking Great
description: How to easily treat wood butcher block counters so they will resist moisture and last forever!Contrary to popular belief, wood countertops are not hard to take care of! If you treat them correctly up front, they will last for decades (even around a sink). One of the top five questions I get about our house (and our old one!) is about our butcher block countertops. We've had wood counters on our islands for around 15 years now. Thanks to my Dad I know the best way to treat them and keep them beautiful for years! I shared how to protect bare wood counters a few years ago, so check out that post to see more detail. I also share how I stained the butcher block in that post. This time I wanted to show you how well they have held up over the past eight years and share how I retreat them every year or so: It's really best to reapply this every six months or so...but as you'll see, it's not absolutely necessary. Ours have held up beautifully even after a year or more.  Overall, the whole island counter has lightened from use, and it was uniform. The only part that was slightly darker was under the tray that I use for hand and dish soap: This post may contain affiliate links for your convenience.I may earn a small commission when you make a purchase through links. See my policies and disclosure page for more information.   Nearly EVERYTHING is easily cleaned off of the wood counters. We've had water condensation sit for hours, water spills, wine, cat vomit 😖 -- all of it. If you treat them well like I'll show you, you won't have any issues keeping them clean.  The only thing that I haven't been able to remove is permanent marker:  Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. title: How To Build a DIY Patio Fire Pit the SAFE Way
description: How to build a wood burning stone fire pit on top of a concrete patio. There are a few safety issues to consider when building a DIY fire pit on a concrete surface. I'm sharing the how-to here!Years ago we had a large patio poured in our back yard. The best part was a 14 foot circular fire pit area we designed off to one side. I shared how this part of the patio looked the day of installation:  One big project I had to hold off on was the DIY fire pit. The concrete contractors advised we wait a bit because the stone for the pit is so heavy. The patio had to cure for a couple of weeks.  Before I started, we got a quote for a small stone retaining wall around the circular fire pit area as well as a fire pit with stone that matched our house. The quote came back at almost DOUBLE what the entire PATIO cost. Lordt.  Soooo we decided to do it ourselves with a kit and it was crazy easy. It doesn't look custom, but it does the job...burns wood. ;) Here's the kit we got from Menards:  Read the full postThis content is property of Thrifty Decor Chick LLC. Plus some things we want to come back and see next time! Continue reading 5 Things We Loved On Our Family Vacation to Dallas, Texas at Young House Love.

title: Our Small Kitchen With Attached Living Area
description: I know a house always evolves to work with a family's changing needs, but I'd say this kitchen and attached sitting area are as close to absolutely done as ever. In fact over the last two years they've held pretty steady - we did update the kitchen light to my dream chandelier that looks like bubbles at a beach sunset. And before that we finally settled on the right seating that fit perfectly into the seating area. But yeah, since then... settled! So it felt like it was finally time to share how it all turned out.
